articles.headline: Share a Car, Risk Your Insurance
articles.snippet: The idea of renting out personal cars has attracted interest from car owners, start-up companies and even venture capitalists. But the insurance industry is a big wet blanket.
articles.abstract: The idea of renting out personal cars has attracted interest from car owners, start-up companies and even venture capitalists. But the insurance industry is a big wet blanket.
articles.lead_paragraph: At first glance, the idea of person-to-person car sharing appears to be the perfect solution to any number of problems.

articles.headline: The Computer’s Next Conquest: Crosswords
articles.snippet: This weekend’s American Crossword Puzzle Tournament in Brooklyn will have 600 of the world’s best crossword players, including the digital Dr. Fill.
articles.abstract: This weekend’s American Crossword Puzzle Tournament in Brooklyn will have 600 of the world’s best crossword players, including the digital Dr. Fill.
articles.lead_paragraph: What’s a 10-letter word for smarty pants?

articles.headline: Putin Needs Higher Oil Prices to Pay for Campaign Promises
articles.snippet: During his presidential campaign, Vladimir V. Putin promised a large increase in government spending, but doing that without busting the Kremlin’s budget would require oil to reach unprecedented prices.
articles.abstract: During his presidential campaign, Vladimir V. Putin promised a large increase in government spending, but doing that without busting the Kremlin’s budget would require oil to reach unprecedented prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In American presidential politics, high oil prices are a problem. For Vladimir V. Putin’s new presidential term in Russia, they will be a necessity — crucial to fulfilling his campaign promises to lift government spending by billions of dollars a year.

articles.headline: Untouchable Pensions May Be Tested in California
articles.snippet: With Stockton, Calif., facing bankruptcy and a $30 million a year pension bill, a provision in the state Constitution that forbids cuts in public pensions will be put to the test.
articles.abstract: With Stockton, Calif., facing bankruptcy and a $30 million a year pension bill, a provision in the state Constitution that forbids cuts in public pensions will be put to the test.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the city manager of troubled Stockton, Calif., had to tell city council members why it was on track to become the biggest American city yet to go bankrupt, it took hours to get through the list.

articles.headline: U.S. Identifies Army Sergeant in Killing of 16 in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, 38, is a father of two who has been injured twice in combat over four deployments.
articles.abstract: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, 38, is a father of two who has been injured twice in combat over four deployments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The military on Friday identified the soldier accused of killing 16 Afghan villagers earlier this week as Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, a 38-year-old father of two who had been injured twice in combat over the course of four deployments and had, his lawyer said, an exemplary military record.

articles.headline: When Businesses Can’t Stop Asking, ‘How Am I Doing?’
articles.snippet: The onslaught of questionnaires from businesses has led to declining response rates and a condition known as survey fatigue, but it’s not likely to let up soon.
articles.abstract: The onslaught of questionnaires from businesses has led to declining response rates and a condition known as survey fatigue, but it’s not likely to let up soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: A commercial transaction, in its simplest form, involves a customer paying for goods or services. But these days, that is just the first step.

articles.headline: Price of Gas Matters to Voters, but Doesn’t Seem to Sway Votes
articles.snippet: There is not much evidence that gas prices deserve an outsize reputation for holding economic and political influence.
articles.abstract: There is not much evidence that gas prices deserve an outsize reputation for holding economic and political influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stacy Hawks is angry that the rising price of gasoline is squeezing the profits of her father’s produce company and draining the wallets of friends who drive trucks. She is angry that the government has not acted to reverse the trend.

articles.headline: A Passionate Persona Forged in a Brutal Defeat
articles.snippet: Rick Santorum lost his Senate seat in a landslide in 2006, but the positions he held during that race have helped rebrand him as the face of conservatism in 2012.
articles.abstract: Rick Santorum lost his Senate seat in a landslide in 2006, but the positions he held during that race have helped rebrand him as the face of conservatism in 2012.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rick Santorum’s prospects for re-election to the Senate were not rosy when friends and advisers urged him in 2005 not to risk making things worse.

articles.headline: Barriers to Change, From Wall St. and Geneva
articles.snippet: The battle to remake the financial markets faces new obstacles in — of all places — the World Trade Organization.
articles.abstract: The battle to remake the financial markets faces new obstacles in — of all places — the World Trade Organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVEN now, after all we’ve been through, something is still wrong with Wall Street.

articles.headline: All Odds Aside, G.O.P. Girding for Floor Fight
articles.snippet: Republicans are preparing for the possibility that their presidential nomination could be decided at the national convention rather than on the campaign trail.
articles.abstract: Republicans are preparing for the possibility that their presidential nomination could be decided at the national convention rather than on the campaign trail.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For the first time in a generation, Republicans are preparing for the possibility that their presidential nomination could be decided at their national convention rather than on the campaign trail, a prospect that would upend one of the rituals of modern politics.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: 63 Years Flying, From Glamour to Days of Gray
articles.snippet: Ron Akana is widely believed to be the longest-serving flight attendant in the United States.
articles.abstract: Ron Akana is widely believed to be the longest-serving flight attendant in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — As the crush of passengers boarded United Flight 618 to Hawaii here last month, they passed by a silver-haired flight attendant in bifocals who greeted them with an “Aloha, welcome aboard.”

articles.headline: Sergeant’s Wife Kept a Blog on the Travails of Army Life
articles.snippet: Karilyn Bales, whose husband, Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, is accused of killing 16 Afghans, posted about life as a military wife.
articles.abstract: Karilyn Bales, whose husband, Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, is accused of killing 16 Afghans, posted about life as a military wife.
articles.lead_paragraph: She detailed her pregnancy, with her husband a world away. She described the knot she got in her stomach from missing him. She wrote of her disappointment after he was passed over for a promotion.

articles.headline: Suspect’s Multiple Tours Call Attention to War Strain
articles.snippet: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, was deployed four times in a decade to Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, was deployed four times in a decade to Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, the soldier accused of killing 16 civilians in Afghanistan last week, was deployed four times to Iraq and Afghanistan over a decade, a record of combat that at the very least suggests high levels of stress. He was particularly upset about being sent to Afghanistan, his wife wrote last year on her blog, and the family had hoped to be stationed in Germany, Italy or Hawaii instead.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and John H. Cushman Jr

articles.headline: In New Office Designs, Room to Roam and to Think
articles.snippet: The 21st-century workplace extols the value of open space, background noise and outside light — and questions the worth of private offices and other signs of hierarchy.
articles.abstract: The 21st-century workplace extols the value of open space, background noise and outside light — and questions the worth of private offices and other signs of hierarchy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE

articles.headline: When Office Technology Overwhelms, Get Organized
articles.snippet: All the new tools in the workplace can leave us dizzy, undermining our ability to get things done. But there are ways to return to a more productive path.
articles.abstract: All the new tools in the workplace can leave us dizzy, undermining our ability to get things done. But there are ways to return to a more productive path.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW do you think most workers would respond if you asked them, “Do you feel more productive now than you did several years ago?” I doubt that the answer would be a resounding yes. In fact, even as workplace technology and processes steadily improve, many professionals feel less productive than ever.

articles.headline: U.S. Faces a Tricky Task in Assessment of Data on Iran
articles.snippet: Discerning the intentions of Iran’s leaders on the crucial steps to building a nuclear bomb is the most covert aspect of one of the world’s most difficult intelligence collection targets.
articles.abstract: Discerning the intentions of Iran’s leaders on the crucial steps to building a nuclear bomb is the most covert aspect of one of the world’s most difficult intelligence collection targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While American spy agencies have believed that the Iranians halted efforts to build a nuclear bomb back in 2003, the difficulty in assessing the government’s ambitions was evident two years ago, when what appeared to be alarming new intelligence emerged, according to current and former United States officials.

articles.headline: In Mexico, a Kidnapping Ignored as Crime Worsens
articles.snippet: Six years into a mostly military assault on drug cartels, impunity has worsened, and justice is harder to find.
articles.abstract: Six years into a mostly military assault on drug cartels, impunity has worsened, and justice is harder to find.
articles.lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — They have spotted their stolen vehicles at stoplights, driven by the same gunmen who used them to take their entire family captive last July. They have reported the brazen abduction to every branch of Mexican law enforcement, only to be ignored, or directed someplace else.

articles.headline: Hawks Steering Debate on How to Take On Iran
articles.snippet: Clear fissures have developed among pro-Israel groups, including among hard-liners themselves, over just how aggressively to confront Iran.
articles.abstract: Clear fissures have developed among pro-Israel groups, including among hard-liners themselves, over just how aggressively to confront Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before President Obama declared this month that “I have Israel’s back” in its escalating confrontation with Iran, pro-Israel figures like the evangelical Christian leader Gary L. Bauer and the conservative commentator William Kristol were pushing for more.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Mark Landler

articles.headline: How ‘Hunger Games’ Built Up Must-See Fever
articles.snippet: A small crew with a tiny marketing budget made gradual use of social media to build interest in a movie with tricky subject matter.
articles.abstract: A small crew with a tiny marketing budget made gradual use of social media to build interest in a movie with tricky subject matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Selling a movie used to be a snap. You printed a poster, ran trailers in theaters and carpet-bombed NBC’s Thursday night lineup with ads.

articles.headline: Apple Says It Will Announce a Decision About Its Cash
articles.snippet: As Apple’s cash balance has piled up, analysts and investors have begun to call more loudly for it to return some of the money to shareholders as dividends.
articles.abstract: As Apple’s cash balance has piled up, analysts and investors have begun to call more loudly for it to return some of the money to shareholders as dividends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has finally decided what to do with its cash hoard of nearly $100 billion.

articles.headline: Theater, Disguised as Real Journalism
articles.snippet: Mike Daisey’s “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs” was a fine bit of theater, but it worked less well as journalism, which was how it was represented in January on “This American Life.”
articles.abstract: Mike Daisey’s “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs” was a fine bit of theater, but it worked less well as journalism, which was how it was represented in January on “This American Life.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Is it O.K. to lie on the way to telling a greater truth? The short answer is also the right one.

articles.headline: Playing at No Cost, Right Into the Hands of Mobile Game Makers
articles.snippet: Many smartphone developers have adopted a lucrative strategy known as freemium: giving away games and then charging for extra features.
articles.abstract: Many smartphone developers have adopted a lucrative strategy known as freemium: giving away games and then charging for extra features.
articles.lead_paragraph: Still paying 99 cents to download a smartphone game? That’s far too much. More developers are now giving their games away — and then charging for extra features.

articles.headline: Drifting Right, Illinois Is Test for Romney
articles.snippet: Illinois has traditionally favored moderate Republicans, but as voters there prepare to go the polls for Tuesday’s Republican primary, Mitt Romney has a fight on his hands.
articles.abstract: Illinois has traditionally favored moderate Republicans, but as voters there prepare to go the polls for Tuesday’s Republican primary, Mitt Romney has a fight on his hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Illinois has been known for choosing Republicans of a moderate brand, in the mold of James R. Thompson, the state’s longest serving governor, or Mark Steven Kirk, the United States senator elected in 2010. So for Mitt Romney, who has had to defend himself against the moderate label elsewhere, a primary here — with its large prize of delegates and the symbolism of President Obama’s backyard — would seem a welcome, natural fit.

articles.headline: Surprise Increase in Rates Is Credited to Signs of Recovery
articles.snippet: Bond yields had their biggest move since October last week, with a sell-off that lifted the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds to 2.31 percent.
articles.abstract: Bond yields had their biggest move since October last week, with a sell-off that lifted the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds to 2.31 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors will be closely watching for another rise in interest rates when trading resumes on Monday, after the bond market’s sharpest move in nearly six months caught some traders by surprise last week.

articles.headline: At Home, Asking How ‘Our Bobby’ Became War Crime Suspect
articles.snippet: Family and friends of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who is accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, say he was a solid young man who was changed by war, but there are also glimpses of a darker story line.
articles.abstract: Family and friends of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who is accused of killing 16 Afghan civilians, say he was a solid young man who was changed by war, but there are also glimpses of a darker story line.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was not the star, just a well-regarded young man who seemed to try to do the right thing. That was Robert Bales, “our Bobby,” friends said. He was a busy, popular kid, but he made time for the autistic man down the block. Other neighborhood boys admired him. As a high school linebacker, he was good enough to be captain, but also gracious enough to help a more talented player take over his starting position. It was good for the team, he said.

articles.headline: A Tale of Greek Enterprise and Olive Oil, Smothered in Red Tape
articles.snippet: Despite the government’s promises to improve, starting a business in Greece remains discouragingly complicated, as is demonstrated by one man’s effort to sell olive products online.
articles.abstract: Despite the government’s promises to improve, starting a business in Greece remains discouragingly complicated, as is demonstrated by one man’s effort to sell olive products online.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — It was about a year ago that Fotis I. Antonopoulos, a successful Web program designer here, decided he wanted to open an e-business selling olive products.

articles.headline: Drones at Issue as U.S. Rebuilds Ties to Pakistan
articles.snippet: The C.I.A.’s pilotless planes hurt militants, but in Pakistan, public discourse rings with thunderous condemnations of breached sovereignty and civilian casualties.
articles.abstract: The C.I.A.’s pilotless planes hurt militants, but in Pakistan, public discourse rings with thunderous condemnations of breached sovereignty and civilian casualties.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Making up is never easy. But as Pakistan and the United States try to restart their troubled relationship after a year of spectacular crises, the difference could come down to drones.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud

articles.headline: Flush With Cash, Apple Plans Buyback and Dividend
articles.snippet: The technology company said it would use some of its $100 billion in cash reserves to pay a quarterly dividend of $2.65 a share beginning this summer.
articles.abstract: The technology company said it would use some of its $100 billion in cash reserves to pay a quarterly dividend of $2.65 a share beginning this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple announced on Monday that it would at last return some of its cash pile to shareholders in the form of dividends and stock buybacks, at a cost of more than $10 billion a year for the next three years. But it is attracting so much cash — $1 billion a week in the last holiday season alone — that the move will not put a dent in Apple’s coffers.
